content.webTitle: The Iraq War: Five Years on: Where are they now?

fields.headline: General Tommy, Chemical Ali - where are they now?
fields.bodyText: Tommy Franks American general who led the 2003 invasion Was described by Donald Rumsfeld as a 'wise commander', despite being derided by critics for an alleged lack of imagination. He has forged a lucrative consulting career in civilian life but was embroiled in controversy earlier this year when it was revealed that he was paid $100,000 to endorse a charity accused of ripping off donors and wounded troops. He later dissociated himself from the group. Paul Bremer Iraq's Civil Administrator after invasion The veteran diplomat appointed by George Bush to run Iraq spent the first two years after his return from Iraq writing his bestselling book, My Year in Iraq: the Struggle to Build a Future of Hope. Since then he has been speaking and lecturing and serves as a director of Catholic Charities in Washington. The group describes itself as the largest provider of social services to the city's population. Paul Wolfowitz Former US Deputy Defence Secretary As the intellectual force behind the Bush neo-conservatives, alongside Richard Perle , he was one of the main advocates of the invasion. In 2005 he became head of the World Bank, but was forced to resign last year following the pay and promotion deals given to his partner, Shaha Riza, who also worked for the bank. He is currently a visiting scholar at think-tank, the American Enterprise Mohammed Saeed Al-Sahaf 'Comical Ali' Insisted that Iraqi forces were repelling the invading coalition forces in 2003, even as US tanks entered Baghdad. The creators of the 'death pack' of cards issued to US troops excluded him, resisting the temptation to include him as the joker. He resurfaced months after the invasion, claiming to have been arrested and released by US forces. Now said to be living with family in the UAE, fan pages dedicated to Saddam's former Information Minister still exist online. Ali Hassan Al-Majid 'Chemical Ali' Got nickname for his role in gas attacks against Kurds in 1988. Saddam's cousin and henchman was also behind the brutal suppression of the abortive southern Shia uprising in 1991. The king of spades in the 'death pack' of cards issued to US troops. He was convicted last year of genocide and sentenced to death by hanging, a sentence approved by Iraq's presidency. Huda Salih Mahdi Ammash 'Chemical Sally' aka 'Mrs Anthrax' The US-educated scientist was accused of playing a part in Iraq's supposed chemical weapons programme. One of the few women in Saddam's inner circle, she appeared as the five of hearts and the 53rd most wanted figure in the so-called 'death pack'. She was said to have been dying from cancer by the time of her release by US forces in December 2005. Tariq Aziz Saddam's Deputy Prime Minister One of the few Christians close to the dictator, he was quickly detained. He appeared as the eight of spades, and the 43rd most wanted figure in the US military's 'death pack'. Following his arrest, The Observer published letters from the cigar-smoking former Deputy Prime Minister in which he proclaimed his innocence and pleaded for help to end his 'dire situation'. Currently still being held, he testified for the defence during the trial of Saddam. The leaders ... and what happened next Tony Blair has become a Middle East peace envoy, while enjoying a lucrative sideline working for two major financial firms. George Bush looks increasingly 'demob happy' as his presidency enters its twilight. Former Spanish President José María Aznar left office in 2004 and runs a conservative think-tank. Colin Powell, the ex-US Secretary of State, has been working as a motivational speaker and as a director for a US healthcare corporation. Dominique de Villepin, who opposed the invasion, quit as France's Prime Minister. Jacques Chirac's premiership ended last May, He is enjoying semi-retirement.
